segments.key_quote: Up till now no one on earth has ever shed tears because of royal negligence.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces and explains the 8th verse of the 17th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, focusing on the king's duty to protect citizens and the unprecedented nature of suffering in Parikshit Maharaj's kingdom.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing from the 8th and 9th verses of the 17th chapter of the first canto of Shri Madhavagavatam. The 8th verse is as follows: Najatu Kauravendranam Dordanda Parirambhite Bhutale Anupatanti Asmin Vinate Praninam Shuchaha. The meaning of this verse is: Now, for the first time in a kingdom well protected by the arms of the kings of the Kuru dynasty, I see you grieving with tears in your eyes. Up till now, no one on earth has ever shed tears because of royal negligence. Parikshit Maharaj is clearly saying that the rulers were so perfect that those deserving protection never had to worry about being neglected by the king or by the government. The law enforcement by the powerful rulers, nobody had to fear any such upstart who would harm the cows or the bulls. Only the human beings did that. So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, "The protection of the lives of both the human beings and animals is the first and foremost duty of a government." Why is the government there at all? It is to give protection to the life. Human life is very precious. This what repeatedly we have heard. It is to give self protection to the life human life is very precious. This is what repeatedly we have heard.

segments.key_quote: is the life of the cow and the bull equally important why human life as you have heard is specially meant for God realization
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of cow protection and Brahmanical culture for spiritual advancement, highlighting the value of human life for God realization and the role of cow's milk in developing finer brain tissues.
segments.transcript: The scriptures, all the scriptures, they say human life is very, very important, so is the life of the cow and the bull, equally important. Why? Human life, as you have heard, is specially meant for God realization, for making a permanent solution to all problems of material existence by becoming God conscious, very simple. And to help us to become God conscious, there is the Brahmanical culture which has to be, which has to be maintained by the spiritual practice, and then the spiritual practice has to be maintained by the spiritual practice, and then the spiritual practice has to be maintained, it has to be maintained brahmanical culture. And Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, is described as namo brahmanya devaya go brahmana hitayaja go brahmana hitayaja. Krishna wants to see that the cows and the brahmanas are especially protected. This is called brahmanical culture because the brahmanas are meant to give direction to the human society to become God-conscious, make spiritual advancement, and get out of this material existence in the human form of life. And for that, the protection for the cow which gives the miracle food, the milk, cow's milk, very, very important for developing the finer brain tissue.

segments.key_quote: It is simply horrible for a pure-hearted soul to see organized animal killing by the state in this age of Kali
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the government's duty to protect animals, particularly cows and bulls, and laments the organized animal killing prevalent in the age of Kali, especially in Western countries.
segments.transcript: Issues to understand spiritual subject matter. So when it is said the lives of both the human beings and animals is first and foremost duty for government, animals particularly refers to cows, cows and bulls, go rupture, that's what is said in the Bhagavad-Gita also. A government must not discriminate in such principles. It's not that only human beings are important and the animals not not important. They don't think it is precious life of an of a cow. They don't think it's very precious. If it is useful you may keep it, if it is not useful you can do whatever you want. So that is very, very wrong. Such a policy by the government, the government is no longer a law to protect the animals. So government must give protection to the cows and bulls as much as the government is meant for giving protection to the human beings. It is simply horrible for a pure-hearted soul to see organized animal killing by the state in this age of Kali. Brahma is talking about pure devotees. Pure devotees, they just can't even imagine that organized animal killing is going on in this age of Kali, supported by the government, supported by the government, especially in the western countries. And there are slaughterhouses where millions of cows are killed and the government is having no laws to protect these animals, innocent animals. People have become heartless and the government also is equally heartless in matter of killing such innocent animals and they suffer so much, they suffer like the human being, like the human being because they have developed.

segments.key_quote: see Pariksit Maharaj is so sensitive because he is Krishna conscious is a pure devotee so he feels for the bull expressing its suffering condition
segments.summary: The speaker highlights Maharaj Parikshit's sensitivity and compassion towards the suffering bull, attributing it to his Krishna consciousness and pure devotion.
segments.transcript: Consciousness, they developed consciousness. Maharaj Pariksit was lamenting for the tears in the eyes of the bull. See, Pariksit Maharaj is so sensitive because he is Krishna conscious, is a pure devotee. So he feels for the bull expressing its suffering condition through tears in the eyes. If a animal is crying it's because it is suffering, it deserves to be protected, deserves to be to be given some relief from suffering by in a helpless condition is appealing for help. So the caretakers, the protectors, just like the Bhagavad Gita it says Vaishyas, they are meant for cow protection, they should give protection. So Maharaj Pariksit was feeling very, very bad about this suffering that the bull is undergoing and he was astonished to see such an unprecedented thing in his good kingdom.

segments.key_quote: Krishna always wants devotees to rule Rajarishi Krishna instructed the devotees to rule Rajarishi Krishna instructed the devotees to rule Rajarishi
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the ideal of God-conscious kings (Rajarishis) and Krishna's desire for devotees to rule, referencing the Suryavamsa and Chandra Vamsa dynasties.
segments.transcript: Unprecedented means in his kingdom never before has such a thing ever happened. Can imagine how good the governance was in Pariksit's time. Wherever he went he heard glorification of Krishna. He heard before this the description was there he had the glorification of the devotees of Krishna, the Pandavas, how nicely they were ruling, everybody was happy, there was prosperity. Earlier chapters described that Krishna particularly arranged the battle of Kurukshetra to to change the rule from Duryodhana's rule to Yudhishthira's rule. Krishna always wants devotees to rule Rajarishi. Krishna instructed the devotees to rule Rajarishi. Krishna instructed the devotees to rule Rajarishi the Bhagavad Gita to the Sun God and later on to Arjuna. Why Sun God? Because he is the ruler of the Sun planet and his descendants are coming in the in the dynasty Suryavamsa dynasty of kings and the there are also another set of rulers coming in the Chandra Vamsa the descendants of the moon dynasty Chandra Vamsa. The Supreme Lord himself appeared in Suryavamsa and Chandra Vamsa. He appeared as Lord Rama in Suryavamsa and he appeared as Krishna in the Chandra Vamsa. So this is the dynasty of God conscious kings. They were Raja, they were kings, they were also saintly kings, Rishi. Rishi means saintly by their conduct, by their behavior, by their character saintly persons.

segments.key_quote: O son of Surabhi you need lament no longer now there is no need to fear this low class Chudra and O mother cow as long as I am living as the ruler
segments.summary: The speaker explains the 9th verse, focusing on Parikshit Maharaj's assurance of protection to the cow and bull, emphasizing the ideal of a kingdom where all are safe and cared for.
segments.transcript: So Parikshit Maharaj was ruling so perfectly that such a insight instance is unprecedented unprecedented. So Prabhupada concludes this purport by telling men and animals were equally protected as far as his life is concerned. That is the way in God's Kingdom. The ninth words: Ma Swarabhe Yatra shucho vreetu te vrushaladbhayam ma odir ambabhadram te kalannatvam. The meaning is: O son of Surabhi, you need lament no longer, now there is no need to fear this low class Chudra and O mother cow, as long as I am living as the ruler and subduer of all envious.

segments.key_quote: protection of bulls and cows and all other animals can be possible only when there is a state ruled by an executive head like Maharaj Pariksit
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of cow protection in state administration, highlighting Parikshit Maharaj's example and explaining the concept of Surabhi cows in the spiritual realm.
segments.transcript: Men, there is no cause for you to cry, everything will be good for you. In the purport, Prabhupada says protection of bulls and cows and all other animals can be possible only when there is a state ruled by an executive head like Maharaj Pariksit. So the protection for the bulls and cows as very very important aspect of the state administration is understood by a God conscious king. Maharaj Pariksit addresses the cow as mother for he is a cultured twice-born kshatriya king, you Amba, that's the way the cow is addressed, mother. Amba means mother. So why? Because he is a qualified kshatriya, is a qualified kshatriya, he's undergone the cultural birth, the second birth dvija by being initiated spiritually initiated, that is the meaning. Surabhi is the name of the cows which exist in the spiritual planets and are especially reared by Lord Shri Krishna himself in Krishna's personal about Goloka. Goloka means the place where cows are specially reared by Krishna by protected by Krishna. They are called Surabhi cows. As men are made after the form and features of the Supreme Lord Krishna, so also the cows are made after the form and features of the Surabhi cows and the kingdom. So the cows on this earth planet what we see they are made after the form and features of Surabhi cows in Krishna's personal about. In the material world the human society gives all protection to the human being but there is no law to protect the descendants Surabhi.

segments.key_quote: the cow and bull needs to be there in such a way that anybody even attempts to harm the cow or the bull immediately they will be killed death penalty
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates the importance of cow protection, emphasizing the nutritional value of milk and the need for strict punishment for cow killers, ultimately linking cow protection to societal peace and well-being.
segments.transcript: All right, now these descendants Surabhi, the cows can give all protection to men by supplying the miracle food milk. Many times Prabhupada is pointed out miracle food milk. It is complete nutrition for the human being. It is most important for development of finer brain tissues to understand spiritual subject matter. But Maharaj Pariksit and the Pandavas were fully conscious of the importance of the carven bull and they were prepared to punish the cow killer with all chastisement including death. So the cow and bull needs to be there in such a way that anybody even attempts to harm the cow or the bull immediately they will be killed, death penalty. There has been some times agitation for protection of cows but because there are no pious executive heads and suitable laws the cow and the bull are not given proper protection in our present times. The human should society should recognize the importance of the cow and bull and thus give all protection to these important animals following in the footsteps of Maharaj Pariksit. See the Bhagavatham is the ideal suggesting the ideal way of ruling the state ideal way of conducting oneself. So Krishna will be pleased when the cows are protected and the brahmanas are protected and Krishna will bestow real peace on the carver and the bull and the cow upon human society in such a situation otherwise we cannot expect peace there will always be.
